sectionTitle: Valuing Level Cash Flows: Annuities and Perpetuities

columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the withdrawal amounts if we have $500,000, and we decided to withdraw each month for the next ten years with an appropriate interest rate of 9%.

Using the prescribed financial calculator to compute the monthly withdrawals, we'll give a result based on the form of an annuity due. An annuity due refers to the cash flow received at the beginning of each period rather than the end.
We'll calculate the monthly withdrawals in a spreadsheet using the PMT function to arrive at the same result. Hence, we'll use the following syntax of the PMT function:

$$\begin{aligned}
PMT&=(\text{rate},nper,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pv$, which represents the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

Proceeding with the calculation, consider the following details; let's first calculate the annual annuity payment.

| Particulars   |          |
|---------------|----------|
| Present value | $500,000 |
| Rate          | 9%       |
| Period        | 10 years |

Let's now calculate the annual annuity payments.
